energy.name: Energy Sector

policy.challenge: Subsidized electricity prices undermine efficiency investments
policy.statistic: Most distribution utilities continue to subsidize retail electricity prices, making efficiency investments less attractive

policy.challenge: Energy efficiency programs remain largely voluntary
policy.statistic: Limited mandatory compliance requirements for building energy codes
Seven major sectors transitioned from PAT to CCTS in December 2025, requiring significant adjustment

financial.challenge: Economic benefits of EE investments cannot be monetized upfront
financial.statistic: High initial costs and uncertain payback periods deter investment

financial.challenge: Limited State Energy Conservation Fund utilization
financial.statistic: SECF is underutilized as a financing instrument for state-level projects
Over 50% reduction in energy efficiency allocations from $16M to $8M in Interim Budget 2024

technical.statistic: Current standard ignores humidity impact, causing up to 25% underestimation of energy use

technical.challenge: Renewable energy scaling constraints beyond 1,500 GW
technical.statistic: Only 29% of wind and 27% of solar potential in areas with population density <250/sq.km
Only 35% of wind and 41% of solar potential in conflict-free areas

behavioral.challenge: Limited consumer awareness of energy-saving technologies
behavioral.statistic: Poor market penetration due to awareness gaps
High costs, limited awareness, and lack of supply chain readiness persist

institutional.challenge: Limited technical and financial capacity at state level
institutional.statistic: Capacity constraints limit scale-up of efficient technologies
Multiple bottlenecks in active policy implementation

institutional.challenge: Labor shortages in energy efficiency sector
institutional.statistic: 18 million people work in EE globally, but persistent shortages in high-growth regions like India

recommendations: Implement firm mandatory building energy codes nationwide
Scale up blended financing mechanisms for efficiency investments
Update testing standards to reflect real-world conditions including humidity
Strengthen State Energy Conservation Funds with better utilization frameworks
Expand energy auditing and management institutional support

transport.name: Transport Sector

policy.challenge: TOD implementation lags despite National Policy since 2017
policy.statistic: Six years after policy, take-off remains slow despite rapid metro expansion

policy.challenge: Motor Vehicles Act restrictions on private operators
policy.statistic: Laws impede competition and restrict high-quality bus service availability

policy.challenge: Gap between state policy and local bylaws
policy.statistic: Deficiencies in land use regulations and coordination between governance levels

financial.challenge: Electric buses 2-3x more expensive than diesel
financial.statistic: High capital costs and financing gaps for EV fleet operators
100% waivers only valid until June 2025, then 25% annual reduction

financial.challenge: Private sector financing barriers for EV charging
financial.statistic: EV-to-public-charger ratio at 235:1 vs 20:1 in mature markets

technical.statistic: Journey must be convenient and connected; fragmented systems deter modal shift
Only 28% of jobs in Bengaluru within 500m of metro stations
29,277 public charging stations as of August 2025, targeting 88,500 under PM E-DRIVE

behavioral.challenge: Steady decline in public transport ridership
behavioral.statistic: Growing incomes drive shift to personal vehicles; 138% PMV growth vs 26% urban population growth

behavioral.challenge: Paradigm shift required from car-oriented planning
behavioral.statistic: Massive training and sensitization needed for planners and public

institutional.statistic: Delhi alone has 10+ agencies handling transport, causing coordination inefficiencies

institutional.challenge: Only 63 of 458 cities with 1 lakh+ population have formal bus networks
institutional.statistic: Majority of smaller cities lack public bus systems
Need for intelligent transport systems, smart card payments, and AVLS integration

recommendations: Enable seamless physical, information, and fare integration across modes
Allocate budget for TOD implementation in metro cities
Revisit Motor Vehicles Act to enable market competition
Scale up PM E-DRIVE charging infrastructure to 88,500 stations
Develop walking and cycling infrastructure within 1km of transit stations

buildings.name: Buildings Sector

policy.challenge: ECBC implementation modest despite notification over decade ago
policy.statistic: 23 states notified ECBC but implementation and compliance remain weak

policy.challenge: Building codes not in local bylaws in accessible language
policy.statistic: Codes missing introduction in implementable format at local level

policy.challenge: No clear definition of thermal comfort in ICAP
policy.statistic: Plan lacks benchmarks for energy efficiency measures for active and passive cooling

financial.challenge: High upfront costs for green building materials
financial.statistic: Operational costs decrease but initial investment remains barrier

financial.challenge: IGBC certification expensive for smaller projects
financial.statistic: Costs for technologies, materials, and consultants deter affordable housing projects
Need for material supplier compendium, certified labor, and cost documentation

technical.challenge: Cooling demand growth outpacing efficiency gains
technical.statistic: Cooling alone could add 500 GW to peak demand by 2035 in India

technical.challenge: Limited access to innovative green technologies
technical.statistic: Technical expertise lacking during design and construction phases
High density and small dwellings make interventions impossible at scale

behavioral.challenge: Stakeholder belief that green buildings cost more
behavioral.statistic: Perception adversely affects greening of building sector

behavioral.challenge: Consumer awareness of ECBC and green building benefits low
behavioral.statistic: Limited market transformation due to awareness gaps

institutional.statistic: Need for empaneling more TPAs for ECBC compliance

institutional.challenge: Buildings account for 30% of global energy demand
institutional.statistic: 50% of countries lack efficiency standards for new buildings
156 Mt CO2e in 2024, projected to reach 329 Mt CO2e by 2035 without intervention

recommendations: Strengthen ECBC compliance frameworks with Third Party Assessor networks
Develop cool roof material supplier compendium and training programs
Shift building codes to passive design principles
Include ECBC in local building bylaws in accessible language
Mainstream district cooling and low-carbon materials in development policies

airQuality.name: Air Quality Sector

policy.challenge: NCAP focuses on PM10 instead of more harmful PM2.5
policy.statistic: Lack of health-driven priorities delays tackling PM2.5 pollution

policy.challenge: NCAP target of 1,500 manual monitoring stations unmet
Differing metrics between CPCB and Star Rating System
policy.statistic: Cities performing well in one metric perform poorly in another, making comparison difficult

financial.statistic: Only 51% of Rs 1,615 crore released until May 2024 has been utilized

financial.challenge: 82 non-attainment cities utilized only 40% of allocated funds
financial.statistic: 498 crore utilized out of 1,253 crore allocated until November 2023

technical.challenge: 28 of 130 cities lack continuous monitoring stations
technical.statistic: Significant gaps in real-time air quality monitoring

technical.challenge: Data quality concerns with CAAQMS stations
technical.statistic: Poor maintenance and non-compliance with CPCB siting guidelines
Only 50 of 130 NCAP cities completed studies, PRANA portal shows only 40

technical.challenge: Air forecasting systems limited to Delhi
technical.statistic: Despite NCAP goal for forecasting in all non-attainment cities by 2022
81% of monitored stacks have >1,000 hours of missing data annually

behavioral.challenge: Limited citizen access to air quality data
behavioral.statistic: CPCB website unresponsive due to high traffic, hampering data access

behavioral.challenge: Only 12% of 4,041 census cities have any air monitoring
behavioral.statistic: 47% of population outside air quality monitoring grid coverage

institutional.challenge: Only central PRANA portal functional despite regional goals
institutional.statistic: Air information centres at regional levels not established as planned by 2020

institutional.challenge: Informal sector lacks legal heat protections
institutional.statistic: 70% of non-agricultural workers in informal sector without policy enforcement

institutional.challenge: Lack of standardized protocols across monitoring networks
institutional.statistic: Interoperability issues limit integration into open data platforms

recommendations: Shift NCAP 2.0 primary focus to PM2.5 with health-driven priorities
Complete CAAQMS installation in remaining 28 cities without continuous monitoring
Accelerate source apportionment studies in remaining NCAP cities
Improve fund utilization with streamlined project approval processes
Establish regional air information centres as originally planned

neighbourhoods.name: Neighbourhoods Sector

policy.challenge: Census data outdated - most recent complete data from 2011
policy.statistic: Census 2027 will be next complete enumeration; current planning uses projections

policy.challenge: Greater Bengaluru Governance Act risks re-centralizing authority
policy.statistic: Local institutions relegated to advisory roles, undermining grassroots democracy
Civic elections delayed since 2020, governance accountability gap

financial.statistic: Cities cannot introduce or revise taxes independently, limiting long-term planning
Cumulative debts of nearly Rs 9,300 crore

technical.challenge: Ward delimitation exercise pending for GBA
technical.statistic: City must be divided afresh with 150 wards per corporation by November 2025

technical.challenge: Complex urban system with varying town growth patterns
technical.statistic: Increasing share of stabilizing towns, decreasing growing towns, emergence of declining towns
Staff and resource allocation between five new corporations is critical hurdle

behavioral.statistic: Few wards conduct regular Ward Committee meetings
Relocatees face new civic responsibilities with differential access to power

institutional.statistic: Pressure needed to ensure meetings are held regularly

institutional.challenge: More than 70% of Mumbai land already built-up
institutional.statistic: City functionally landlocked, outward expansion not viable

institutional.challenge: Multiple ward-level problems with inadequate governance
institutional.statistic: Felled trees, broken utilities, garbage, potholes at lowest tier of governance
Only 10 fellows selected for National Urban Youth Fellowship 2025

recommendations: Devolve financial powers to city governments for independent tax administration
Mandate quarterly ward reports and service-level benchmark disclosures
Establish open data portals for transparent civic data access
Strengthen capacity building for municipal staff and elected representatives
Ensure citizen participation through regular Ward Committee meetings
Integrate climate and gender audits into all major urban projects

crossCuttingChallenges.description: Outdated census data (2011), inconsistent monitoring protocols, poor data quality in air monitoring, and missing industrial emissions data hamper evidence-based planning across all sectors
Multiple agencies with overlapping mandates in transport, buildings, and urban governance create coordination challenges and implementation delays
Consistent underutilization of allocated funds across NCAP, energy efficiency, and urban development programs despite availability of resources
Shortage of trained professionals for energy auditing, Third Party Assessment, TOD planning, and municipal governance
Consumer awareness gaps and entrenched preferences for personal vehicles and conventional building practices limit adoption of sustainable alternatives
